posts.name: Ryan Hubbs
posts.cooked: After our competition season we have started to notice Neo 550 motors attached to our MaxSwerve randomly smoking after around 10 seconds of the robot being enabled. Almost always after they start smoking they either work normally after a power cycle (then smoke again). So after replacing countless Neo 550s on our drivetrain I realized the common theme about all of the “broken” motors. All of them have a broken off wire on the 6 pin JST connector that gives feedback to the SparkMax. Why would Rev allow their hardware to deliver current that will cause their motors to start smoking, and probaly become a fire risk if not immediately stopped, under what seems like a known common problem for the Rev motors that use this wire? Does anyone know of a better way to stop the encoder cable wires from breaking so easily and randomly? There is also no easy way to remove the encoder wires from the SparkMax’s port for them. Also does this cause any damage to the actual motor?? After the fix the motor works completely normally.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
Same issues happened to a few of our Neo 550s

Not sure why they chose such small gauge wire for a robotics competition part. The JST-PH connector allows up to 24awg, but I think they’re using 26 or 28 awg wire which is too fragile

posts.name: Ryan Hubbs
posts.cooked: The Rev website claims it is 24AWG wire on the encoder wire. I definately do not think it is 24AWG on the actual product.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: This has been a complaint of mine from the day we got our very first neo + sparkMax. It’s way way way too fragile. And a pain to try to fix. It’s better to chop that connector off and do them all fresh. Otherwise you mangle the JST housing plastic trying to get the old one out, in such a way that the new one never stays again.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
ryanhubbs:

Also does this cause any damage to the actual motor?? After the fix the motor works completely normally.

Probably, but maybe not.

In general, a stalled motor has to dissipate any input power as heat energy - it’s running at 0% efficiency.

The longer the motor sits stalled, the more heat energy is dumped into the physical components of the motor. Since there’s probably more heat energy going into the motor than the environment is wicking away, the temperature of different components increases.

Smoke generally happens when the plastics used to insulate wires in the windings reach a temperature where they chemically break down and vaporize.

Just because you started to break down the insulation doesn’t mean it’s lost all its insulating properties - it might still function as an insulator.

Furthermore, within the motor windings themselves… it’s often not the end of the world if two wires in the same winding get shorted. The total short will decrease the total length of that winding (lowering the resistance, reducing its ability to produce a magnetic field to rotate the motor…). However, you could get lucky and create a short that is negligible.

So… just seeing a bit of smoke doesn’t guarantee that you’ve broken the motor.

However

Seeing any smoke is an indicator the motor is very likely to fail earlier than it usually would have.

In the context of FRC , if you have the ability to replace the motor (or at least relegate the functional-but-smokey one to your “no other choice” backup pile), I’d highly recommend doing so. Not worth the risk of being toasted for a whole match.

posts.name: Ryan Hubbs
posts.cooked: We have replaced at least 3 motors from this issue and I feel like this is literally just something Rev can fix with a SparkMax firmware update. I don’t get why the SparkMax will give a motor the current to starting burning the coating of the motor winding. We already had to buy a bunch of backups because of this specific reason.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
How do you suggest this software function?

The motor controller is getting feedback on position of the motor rotor from hall affect sensors. The valid electrical states are High and Low - so an Open Circuit (lets call it HIGH with a pullup input on the motor controller), is a VALID state.

So rotor position is “known” - and current is sent to the appropriate winding…but in the case a position sensor wire is broken current is then sent to an incorrect winding causing your motor stall and overheat…but your position indicator is not fault tolerant so the motor controller doesn’t know that…

Beyond that, a motor could be stalled mechanically even if electrically its fine. Perhaps in your application you want it to continue to apply torque and as much as it can because you have engineered your feature to be fault tolerant and you know the fault will clear before the motor burns up.

Or perhaps you dont know that the fault will clear and you want to protect your motor - you could then use motor current limits in the motor controller as your protection mechanism as suggested here

All in all - this is more complicated than just a “firmware update”…you get to choose your own adventure. YOU as the designer have the power, but also the responsibility to set correct current limits for your design. As far as responding to a fault - there may be a way to do it, but it will take many design hours, weeks, months, and potentially hardware updates to accommodate this requirement, which may not be worth it (ROI), in the end product.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Look for threads on current limiting NEO550s.  If your motors are getting hot enough to give off smoke as you describe, they are probably not going to last very long before they fail.  Broken wires will sometimes trigger a “sensor fault” – much depends on which wires are broken.  But you need to figure out why your wires are breaking so much.  Yes, these are prone to breaking – but with some care, they have lasted through multiple seasons for several teams I know.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
ryanhubbs:

I don’t get why the SparkMax will give a motor the current to starting burning the coating of the motor winding.

Because it’s time dependent - you can give that current for a short period of time, but not much longer.

This can be done in software by setting current limits (and maybe changing them over time).

If you’re looking for the next step (detecting all faults with the sensor and taking additional action), well… that’s dependent on their hardware. They could possibly make some more-conservative choices… but that might start to produce false-positives, causing good motors to go into a “limp” mode.

Pick your poison

posts.name: Ryan Hubbs
posts.cooked:
nuttle:

Look for threads on current limiting NEO550s.

gerthworm:

This can be done in software by setting current limits (and maybe changing them over time).

Jwal:

YOU as the designer have the power, but also the responsibility to set correct current limits for your design.

A current limit will not solve anything for a few reasons.

We are using a smart current limit of 20 amps on our Neo 550s.

We are using the Neo 550 in the Rev MaxSwerve module which are assembled per their guide.

We are using the Rev MaxSwerve code provided by Rev, including their default current limits!

We are doing everything properly and from what I can tell is solely from a single wire being broken in the JST-PH connector that goes into the Spark Max.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Focusing on preventing the wire breakage is probably going to be the way forward.

But, the answer to why a broken wire leads to this failure mode may depend on which wires are broken.  Two wires are power and ground, three are for the sensor on each of the three phases, and one is for monitoring temperature.

If you loose power or ground, you will probably not get information from anything else.  If you loose a phase sensor or temperature, it’s probably not quite as bad – but loosing any of these wires is going to be a problem.

The only way to really be sure of how loss of one of these wires leads to smoke requires knowledge of the implementation details of the SPARK MAX, including the firmware it is running (checking to be sure you are on current firmware is a good idea regardless).  You will probably have to ask REV.  But it’s a know thing that these wires are a weak link, so to speak.

posts.name: Ryan Hubbs
posts.cooked:
nuttle:

knowledge of the implementation details of the SPARK FLEX

Want to be clear we are using a Neo 550 and SparkMax, not a Vortex and FLEX. Not sure if that was a typo.

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked: Typo – fixed.

posts.name: Robertson Robotics
posts.cooked: Can anyone report if the patches work because I can’t figure out where to put the gum?

posts.name: Brett B Bonner
posts.cooked:
ryanhubbs:

Does anyone know of a better way to stop the encoder cable wires from breaking so easily and randomly?

Yes; this is a frequent topic of discussion on CD .  These wires are the Achilles’ heel of the SparkMax+Neo/Neo550.

Best practice from our experience with SparkMaxes is:

Zip-tie the sensor wires to the motor power wires within 1.5" or so of the controller.  This acts as a strain relief; the wires almost always break at the crimp point, so if you prevent it from flexing there, you largely solve the problem.  Of course, be sure when you do this that there is a bit of slack on the sensor wire.

Add a bit of hot glue where the wires enter the JST (and once it’s plugged in, a bit more to hold the plug in the SparkMax).  Don’t go nuts with it, just use enough to add some mechanical support of the wires where they enter the connector.

You should do the same on the CAN connector/power input side; those use the same connector type and only marginally sturdier wire.

Plus, train anyone who works on the robot to be GENTLE with these wires, and gently pry the connector loose when disconnecting - do not yank on the wires themselves.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
You use the gum to help keep the encoder connector from popping out. Like how some teams use hot-glue. The neo 550 absorbs it into the exposed copper in the crimps.

On this note none of the current generation motors are over 21 years old so none of them should be able to get patches/gum or smoke anyways.

/J

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Neo 550 failure rates have been such a problem for us that we have been trying switching hd hex motors in for them (so far it doesn’t look promising just due to their lower power)

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: This my (yearly?) reminder that these JST 06-KR-6H-P IDC connectors make for easy repairs to Neo signal cables.  They sit pretty flush with the Spark Max however, so require extra care when plugging in and out.
